description: We have agreed to have our build project meetings on the 4th Tuesday of the month for the next few months to dedicate time to work on the project.

name: [Zoom] Debugging with Postgres
description:
Please RSVP here to receive connection details:

https://postgresconf.org/conferences/postgres-webinar-series/tickets

Depending on the project, debugging can take 50 to 90% of development time. But it usually gets less than 10% of the press. PostgreSQL has great tools for debugging, but they are most effective when deployed as part of an overall strategy.

We will look at strategies for debugging PostgreSQL: how to find bugs, how to fix them, and how to keep them from happening in the first place.

We’ll look at root causes, technical tricks, and scientific strategies, and why — even if you can’t always write perfect code — it is usually a good idea to try.

We’ll hear from Bjarne Stroustrup, Sherlock Holmes, Kernighan and Ritchie, Pogo, & the experts of the PostgreSQL community.

Goal: less time debugging, more time building great tools and apps that stay up & get the job done.

name: DevOpsDays Denver 2020
description:
Join us at DevOps Days.

DevOpsDays is back for its 6th annual event in the Rocky Mountains Tuesday, Aug 11, 2020 - Wednesday, Aug 12, 2020! Our pre-registration event will be the evening of Monday, Aug 10, 2020. We're excited to return to Mile High Station again this year.

For More info and sign up, please visit here: https://devopsdays.org/events/2020-denver/welcome/

name: Boulder Blockchain - REMOTE FIRST
description:
Come nerd out about blockchain technology and cryptocurrency with other Boulder-based blockchain enthusiasts.

For 2020 we are trying a new format on the first Friday of every month. Drinks and casual conversation starting at 5pm with our normal roundtable discussions starting at 6pm.

New to Blockchain/Cryptocurrencies? Watch these videos before the meetup:
• 2.5 minute summary of blockchain technology (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6WG7D47tGb0)
• 5.5 minute summary of how the bitcoin blockchain works (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t5JGQXCTe3c)

Can't make the meetup? Join us on Slack (http://www.slackpass.io/coloradoblockchain), where the conversation is always active!
how_to_find_us: Peregrine is located in the Riverside building. Use the main entrance on Broadway. Free 1.5 hour parking across Broadway and at the library.

name: Outdoor Bitcoin Get-Together
description:
Summer is here and it's about time we get back to our normal life as much as possible. This event will respect physical distancing between parties, wear masks when appropriate, and we can safely enjoy each others company.

With that said it should be a beautiful summer day where we can play around and have a great discussion on Bitcoin!

We will have to take precaution in these uncertain times. Please bring food, chairs, and blankets for yourselves. I'll have some snacks, extra gloves, mask, and sanitizer. Plus a couple of frisbee's! Looking forward to seeing everyone who can make it!

name: VIRTUAL: Community Gathering
description:
* Until further notice, all events will happen DIGITALLY *

Join us on Veertly (https://veertly.com) - a web based video conferencing tool. A dial-in number is also available.

***NOTE: if you have issues with veertly - please let Dan know here on meetup on on keybase to help you resolve them.***

We will share a link and call-in number to all that RSVP to this event the day of to call in **via email and keybase**

---

This weekly meetup is a community driven gathering on all things Crypto, Blockchain, and Distributed Ledger Technologies. We enjoy diving deep and conversing the most important aspects of these new technologies. Active participation is highly encouraged! Come prepared with any questions or topics you want to dive into. Better yet - come with something to speak about or teach everyone!

Among us, there is no such thing as a stupid question or topic. Everyone at any level of knowledge is welcome!

Some running topics include:

Discussion of news highlights from the week
Understanding the fundamentals: how it all works and why
Deep dives into software architecture and structure
Demos of basic development of blockchains and Dapps
Getting started with a crypto exchange
Different wallet types and hands-on demos of use
Security and privacy in crypto
What to look for in evaluating potential investments
Trading and Technical Analysis (TA)
Regulatory, Tax, and Legal best-practices
Legislative news and how to get involved

***Refreshments are typically available! And it is more than alright to bring dinner in! Maybe event extra to share with the group :)
how_to_find_us: We will share a Veertly link to all that RSVP to this event the day of to call

name: Hyperledger Avalon and Chainlink
description:
Please join us for the fourth in a series of virtual meetups from the Denver Hyperledger Chapter. This meetup will feature a development presentation from Chainlink along with a presentation from a core maintainer of Hyperledger Avalon. Eugene Yarmosh, the lead architect of Hyperledger Avalon, will be presenting about their technology and use of decentralized oracles.

Hyperledger Avalon is a ledger independent implementation of the Trusted Compute Specifications published by the Enterprise Ethereum Alliance. It aims to enable the secure movement of blockchain processing off the main chain to dedicated computing resources. Avalon is designed to help developers gain the benefits of computational trust and mitigate its drawbacks.

Eugene is a systems architect at Intel who has over 20 years of experience designing and building distributed and decentralized solutions spanning from embedded firmware to large scale cloud solutions. During last several years Eugene focuses on scalability and confidentiality for public and private blockchains, specifically on utilizing trusted execution environments for off-chain workload execution. Eugene is a co-editor of the EEA Off-chain Trusted Compute Specification and he is a lead architect and maintainer of the Hyperledger Avalon – a reference implementation of the Trusted Compute specification. He holds several patents.

Join from PC, Mac, Linux, iOS or Android:

https://zoom.us/my/hyperledger.community

Or iPhone one-tap : US: [masked],,[masked]# or [masked],,[masked]#

Or Telephone: Dial (for higher quality, dial a number based on your current location): US: [masked] or [masked] or [masked] (Toll Free) or [masked] (Toll Free) Meeting ID:[masked] International numbers available: https://zoom.us/u/bAaJoyznp

name: IPFS Community Meetup
description:
REGISTER ON CROWDCAST FOR MORE DETAILS

Connect with the IPFS Community on Monday, August 3rd for a virtual Meetup starting at 4 pm UTC / 12 pm ET / 9 am PT.

We’re excited to gather the IPFS community for a virtual meetup on August 3rd. Join us as we dive deeper into our latest releases and meet the IPFS core developers and many of the builders that are deploying IPFS into production.

THIS EVENT ABIDES BY THE IPFS COMMUNITY CODE OF CONDUCT
https://github.com/ipfs/community/blob/master/code-of-conduct.md

name: Julia Meetup

group.name: Boulder Data Science, Machine Learning & AI

description:
This is the Monthly Julia Meetup that meets on the first Thursday of every month. For the next few months, we will be doing a deep dive of a "Package of the Month".

This month will be a discussion of LightGraphs.jl (https://github.com/JuliaGraphs/LightGraphs.jl) led by Logan Cerkovnik.

Zoom Meeting:
https://us02web.zoom.us/j/891777250

name: DevOps Boulder Monthly!
description: Join us for the monthly DevOps Boulder meeting. Food and drink provided, come and hang out with a bunch of interesting folks!
how_to_find_us: Take 30th north from Pearl, and turn right on Steelyards St.  You can park (free parking!) in any of the 2 hour surface spots, or there is an underground parking garage (also free!) that is accessed from the south end of the surface lot.
